internal_category.title: Section: 10.02 GAUSS ELIMINATION AS LU FACTORIZATION
Subtopic: GAUSS ELIMINATION AS LU FACTORIZATION
ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem: Identify the total flops as a function of the number of equations n for the each case of the LU factorization version of Gauss elimination.

internal_category.title: Section: 10.02 GAUSS ELIMINATION AS LU FACTORIZATION
Subtopic: GAUSS ELIMINATION AS LU FACTORIZATION
ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
The flop counts for LU decomposition can be determined in a similar fashion as was done for Gauss elimination. The major difference is that the elimination is only implemented for the left-hand side coefficients.

Thus, for every iteration of the inner loop, there are n multiplications/divisions and n – 1 additions/subtractions.

The computations can be summarized as

 

Outer Loop

k

Inner Loop

i

Addition/Subtraction

flops

Multiplication/Division

flops
1 2, n (n – 1)(n – 1) (n – 1)n
2 3, n (n – 2)(n – 2) (n – 2)(n – 1)
. .    
. .    
. .    
k k + 1, n (n – k)(n – k) (n – k)(n + 1 – k)
. .    
. .    
. .    
n – 1 n, n (1)(1) (1)(2)

 

 

Therefore, the total addition/subtraction flops for elimination can be computed as

 

%media:formula6.mml%

 

Applying some of the relationships from the equation [A] = [U]T[U] yields

 

%media:formula8.mml%

 

A similar analysis for the multiplication/division flops yields

 

%media:formula7.mml%

 

%media:formula9.mml%

 

Summing these results gives

 

%media:formula11.mml%

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The total flops as a function of the number of equations n for the factorization is as follows:

 

%media:formula5.mml%

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How many number of multiplication flops and subtraction flops are for factorization?

property.value:
For forward substitution, the numbers of multiplications and subtractions are the same and they equal to

 

%media:formula17.mml%

 

Summing the results of multiplications and subtractions gives

 

n2 – n

n2 – n

internal_category.title: Section: 10.02 GAUSS ELIMINATION AS LU FACTORIZATION
Subtopic: GAUSS ELIMINATION AS LU FACTORIZATION
ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
Back substitution is the same as for Gauss elimination:

n2/2 – n/2 subtractions and n2/2 + n/2 multiplications/divisions.

Summing the results of multiplications and subtractions gives n2.

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The total flops as a function of the number of equations n for the backward substitution is as follows:

n2

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How many addition/subtraction flops are there for backward substitution phase of the LU factorization version of Gauss elimination?

multipleChoice.commonFeedback:
Back substitution is the same as for Gauss elimination:

n2/2 – n/2 subtractions and n2/2 + n/2 multiplications/divisions.

Summing the results of multiplications and subtractions gives n2.

worksheet.stem:
Using the rules of matrix multiplication, click and drag the given steps to prove that [L][U] = [A] and [L]{d} = {b} follow from [L]{[U]{x}–{d}} = [A]{x} – {b}.

 

(Note: First prove [L][U] = [A], then [L]{d} = {b}.)

 

__A__

doc.stem:
Develop an M-file that will determine the LU factorization of a square matrix without partial pivoting. That is, develop a function that is passed the square matrix and returns the triangular matrices [L] and [U].

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The lower and upper triangular matrices for the given system of equations are as follows:

 

%media:formula23.mml% and %media:formula24.mml%

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which MATLAB function is used to get the identity matrix?

worksheet.stem:
Using the M-file, solve the given system of equations. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The lower and upper triangular matrices for the given system of equations are as follows:

 

%media:formula21.mml% and %media:formula22.mml%

 

where,

a = __1__

b = __2__

c = __3__

d = __4__

e = __5__

f = __6__

g = __7__

h = __8__

i = __9__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Here is an M-file to generate the LU decomposition without pivoting:


function [L, U] = LUNaive(A)
% LUNaive(A):
% LU decomposition without pivoting.
% input:
% A = coefficient matrix
% output:
% L = lower triangular matrix
% U = upper triangular matrix
[m,n] = size(A);
if m~=n, error('Matrix A must be square'); end
L = eye(n);
U = A;
% forward elimination
for k = 1:n-1

for i = k+1:n
L(i,k) = U(i,k)/U(k,k);
U(i,k) = 0;
U(i,k+1:n) = U(i,k+1:n)-L(i,k)*U(k,k+1:n);
end
end

 

>> A = [10 2 -1;-3 -6 2;1 1 5];
>> [L,U] = LUNaive(A)
L =
1.0000    0        0
–0.30000  1.0000   0
0.1000    -0.1481  1.0000
U =
10.0000  2.0000   -1.0000
0        –5.4000  1.7000
0        0        5.3519

internal_category.title: Section: 10.02 GAUSS ELIMINATION AS LU FACTORIZATION
Subtopic: GAUSS ELIMINATION AS LU FACTORIZATION

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
Verification that [L][U] = [A].

>> L*U
ans =
      10.0000   2.0000   –1.0000
      -3.0000  -6.0000    2.0000
      1.0000    1.0000    5.0000

Check using the lu function,

 

>> [L,U]=lu(A)
L =
   1.0000         0        0
  -0.3000    1.0000        0
   0.0000   -0.1481   1.0000

U =

   10.0000    2.0000   -1.0000
         0   -5.4000    1.7000
         0         0    5.3519

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How do you multiply two matrices?

yesNo.stem: If [L] is a lower triangular matrix, [U] is an upper triangular matrix, and [A] is a coefficient matrix, then [L][U] ≠ [A].
yesNo.commonFeedback:
Verification that [L][U] = [A].

>> L*U
ans =
      10.0000   2.0000   –1.0000
      -3.0000  -6.0000    2.0000
      1.0000    1.0000    5.0000

Check using the lu function,

 

>> [L,U]=lu(A)
L =
   1.0000         0        0
  -0.3000    1.0000        0
   0.0000   -0.1481   1.0000

U =

   10.0000    2.0000   -1.0000
         0   -5.4000    1.7000
         0         0    5.3519

yesInfo.feedback:
Verification that [L][U] = [A].

>> L*U
ans =
      10.0000   2.0000   –1.0000
      -3.0000  -6.0000    2.0000
      1.0000    1.0000    5.0000

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How to perform Cholesky factorization on a matrix?

worksheet.stem:
Use Cholesky factorization to determine [U] so that

 

%media:formula34.mml%

 

(Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The value of matrix [U] is

 

%media:formula39.mml%

where,

a = __1__

b = __2__

c = __3__

d = __4__

e = __5__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Using MATLAB

 

>> A=[[a(1)] -1 0;-1 2 -1;0 -1 2];
>> U=chol(A)
U =
[a(2)] [a(3)]    0
0             [a(4)]    [a(5)]
0             0               [a(6)]


The result can be validated by


>> U'*U
ans =
[a(1)].0000       -1.0000  0
-1.0000   2.0000    -1.0000
0                  -1.0000   2.0000
